<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_getattr:
```c
lfs_ssize_t lfs_getattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_getattr(%p, \"%s\", %"PRIu8", %p, %"PRIu32")",
            (void*)lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    lfs_ssize_t res = lfs_getattr_(lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_getattr -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_getattr:
static lfs_ssize_t lfs_getattr_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type,
                id, lfs_min(size, lfs->attr_max)),
            buffer);
    if (tag < 0) {
        if (tag == LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            return LFS_ERR_NOATTR;
        }

        return tag;
    }

    return lfs_tag_size(tag);
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the code does not modify function parameters themselves. The wrapper lfs_getattr only passes parameters to lfs_getattr_ and macros LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK/LFS_TRACE do not alter the parameter variables. In lfs_getattr_ all other uses of pointer parameters either pass them by value (e.g. path to lfs_dir_get as part of tag construction, size) or pass pointers to objects intended to be modified (e.g. buffer passed to lfs_dir_get modifies the pointed-to object, which is permitted). Local variables (cwd, tag, id) are local and do not constitute modification of function parameters. Therefore only the call passing &path (address of the parameter) is suspicious under MISRA C Rule 17.8 because it allows the callee to modify the pointer parameter itself.
